newsitem.title: USA: Bank robber "Commander Pedro" convicted in Ohio.
newsitem.headline: Bank robber "Commander Pedro" convicted in Ohio.

text.p: A man who called himself "Commander Pedro" was convicted Monday by a federal jury of two bank robberies in Ohio.
Peter Kevin Langan, 38, faces 35 years to life in prison without parole on three different charges involving bank robbery, Dale Ann Goldberg, U.S. Attorney for Ohio's southern district, said.
He also faces trial for assault on federal agents in connection with his arrest in a shootout in Columbus in January 1996, she said.
Langan and four others were also indicted by a federal grand jury last month in Philadelphia for conspiracy to rob banks, eastern Pennsylvania U.S. Attorney Michael Stiles said.

That indictment named Langan, Mark William Thomas of Macungie, Pa., Scott Anthony Stedeford, also called "Tuco," of Ardmore, Pa., Kevin William McCarthy, also called "Blondie," of Philadelphia, and Michael Willaim Brescia, or "Tim," of Philadelphia.
It charged that they recruited young people to rob banks and used false identifies to rent "safe houses," buy getaway cars and register at motels.

That indictment also named Richard Lee Guthrie Jr., called "Wild Bill" or "Commander Pavell." Guthrie, 38, pleaded guilty in Cincinnati to 19 bank robberies but was found hanged in his jail cell last year.
